title: Proof by infinite descent
summary: In mathematics, a proof by infinite descent, also known as Fermat's method of descent, is a particular kind of proof by contradiction[1] used to show that a statement cannot possibly hold for any number, by showing that if the statement were to hold for a number, then the same would be true for a smaller number, leading to an infinite descent and ultimately a contradiction.[2] It is a method which relies on the well-ordering principle, and is often used to show that a given equation, such as a Diophantine equation, has no solutions.[3][4]
